Responding to the realities of creating as people of color during these extraordinary times, Providence-based multimedia artist Carlos Andres Toro of Steer Forward (and our frequent collaborator) alongside composer/violinist Daniel Bernard Roumain offer an online live stream cinematic journey in film and sound.

Combining bold, dramatic imagery with a string and beat-based score, Requiem for the Living, In Color addresses the realities of living in modern-day America, where the inherent worth of black and brown bodies and souls requires impassioned pleas for their humanity to be recognized.

The event will be live this Friday @ 7pm here: https://loom.ly/ErrfuLU

Congratulations to the new District Teacher of the Year, Dr. Michael Clancy!

Dr. Clancy is a founder of RINI and has been with the school and founding team since 2011! He has seen the evolution and can certainly tell stories of "the olden days"! Dr. Clancy is a beloved teacher who challenges students but supports them in everything they do. His college students will tell you that he is a very demanding teacher, but that he has a heart of gold. Each year, Dr. Clancy is mentioned specifically by the students in the senior events, and there is always a huge round of applause and tremendous appreciation for all that he has done for his students.
Dr. Clancy has always supported students as teacher, professor, and college transition coordinator. This year, he added to his role and has been supporting teachers in the nursing workforce department. Everyone who knows Mike Clancy will surely agree that he deserves to be recognized and celebrated for all that he has done and continues to do for RINI.

Each awardee is nominated by school administrators.

Mrs. Salomone has been part of the RINI team since 2013.
She is the science department instructional coach and has been instrumental in curriculum development. Mrs. Salomone has also led the extra-curricular paint club and designed and taught the RINI Art in Health and Medicine course which is a challenging anatomy-based STEAM class. Next year, Mrs. Salomone will also teach a new course called Anatomical Theatre in which students will study the historical developments in art and medicine.

She shared a very personal story of her challenges and struggles on her journey through the nursing career path that she continues to be on. Dr. Heredia explained to students the importance of staying committed to themselves and to their goals and she emphasized the importance of public health and making the community stronger and a better place for all. This was part of RINI‚Äôs World of Nursing week in which students began a career exploration about the many opportunities and paths that are available in nursing. Students were able to participate in the discussion and they asked many questions in order to more fully understand the perspective of an expert in the field and someone that they could easily relate to.
